title: Can you solve the secret werewolf riddle? - Daniel Finkel

multiple-choice.question: You have a rare werewolf antidote in the form of a square that weighs 50 grams, and the minimum effective dose is 10 grams. You have a laser-cutting tool that can cut a square into as many pieces as you want, as long as you can group them into 10-gram portions. If you have 8 points that can act as starting or ending points for each cut, how many cuts can you make at most?
You need to divide the antidote into perfect fifths. What is the shape of the pieces you will get after making the four cuts (from B to E, D to G, F to A, and H to C)?

options.label: A
options.text: It makes it easier to divide the square into fifths

options.label: B
options.text: It makes it allows for more precise cuts

options.label: C
options.text: It makes it easier to experiment and find a solution

options.label: D

title: Why we say “OK”

multiple-choice.question: What is the origin of the word "OK"?

options.label: A
options.text: It comes from the Choctaw word 'okeh', which means 'so it is.'

options.label: B
options.text: It was first used in the 1840 presidential campaign of Van Buren.

options.label: C
options.text: It originated from an 1830s fad of intentionally misspelling abbreviations.

options.label: D
options.text: It was coined by a group of linguists in Boston.

multiple-choice.question: What was the significance of the telegraph in the adoption of the word "OK"?

options.label: A
options.text: It made the word "OK" harder to communicate.

options.label: B
options.text: It led to the decline of the word "OK" in usage.

options.label: C
options.text: It made the word "OK" easy to transmit and adopt as a standard acknowledgement.

options.label: D
options.text: It had no impact on the adoption of the word "OK".

multiple-choice.question: What is the visual strategy behind the popularity of the letter "K"?

options.label: A
options.text: It's because the letter "K" is very common in the English alphabet.

options.label: B
options.text: It's because the letter "K" is very rare in the English alphabet.

options.label: C
options.text: It's because modifying a word with a "K" draws more attention to it.

options.label: D
options.text: It's because the letter "K" is very easy to write.

multiple-choice.question: What does Allan Metcalf say is the meaning of the word "OK"?

options.label: A
options.text: It conveys strong feelings and emotions.

options.label: B
options.text: It affirms without evaluating, meaning it doesn't convey any feelings.

options.label: C
options.text: It's a reflex that we don't even keep track of how much we use it.

options.label: D
options.text: It's a word that's only used in formal situations.

multiple-choice.question: What is notable about the usage of the word "OK" in everyday language?

options.label: A
options.text: We use it very sparingly and only in formal situations.

options.label: B
options.text: We use it very frequently, but mostly in Boston.

options.label: C
options.text: We use it very frequently, but mostly in writing.

options.label: D
options.text: We use it very frequently, but don't even keep track of how much we use it.

title: Your brain hallucinates your conscious reality - Anil Seth

options.label: B

options.label: D
options.text: They had a feeling of intense pain.

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the brain's role in perception?

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: The brain combines sensory signals with prior expectations to form its best guess of what's out there.

options.label: C
options.text: The brain only perceives the world through visual signals.

options.label: D
options.text: The brain only perceives the world through auditory signals.

options.text: To test the limits of human perception.

options.label: C

options.label: D

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the main difference between experiences of the body from the inside and experiences of the world around us?

options.label: A
options.text: Experiences of the body from the inside are more vivid than experiences of the world around us.

options.label: B
options.text: Experiences of the body from the inside are more abstract than experiences of the world around us.

options.label: C
options.text: Experiences of the body from the inside are not about figuring out what's there, but about control and regulation.

options.label: D
options.text: Experiences of the body from the inside are not related to sensory signals from the body.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's main argument about the nature of consciousness?

options.label: A
options.text: Consciousness is a product of the brain's ability to process information.

options.label: B
options.text: Consciousness is a fundamental aspect of the universe that cannot be explained by science.

options.label: C
options.text: Consciousness is a controlled hallucination generated by the brain's predictions and sensory signals.

options.label: D
options.text: Consciousness is a product of the interaction between the brain and the environment.

title: Can you solve the stolen rubies riddle? - Dennis Shasha

multiple-choice.question: A merchant has 30 exquisite Burmese rubies and is being fined for his corrupt dealings. options.label: A
options.text: Each box must contain exactly 6 more rubies than another.

options.label: B

options.text: Each box must contain exactly 30 rubies.

options.label: C
options.text: Write three numbers that are as close to 30 as possible.

options.label: D

options.text: Most chickens are raised in organic farms

title: Why should you read "Don Quixote"? - Ilan Stavans

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the protagonist in Don Quixote who charges an army of giants, believing them to be real?
What was the profession of Miguel de Cervantes before he became a successful author?
What was the main purpose of Don Quixote, according to its creator Miguel de Cervantes?

options.label: B
options.text: To challenge the repetitive chivalry novels of his time

options.label: C
options.text: To create a story about a knight who fights real giants

options.label: D
options.text: To write a satirical novel about medieval culture

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of Don Quixote's squire, who often tries to reason with him and is a study in opposites to the knight's idealism?
What is the name of the lady that Don Quixote believes he is fighting for, although she is not a real person?

title: How QWERTY conquered keyboards

multiple-choice.question: Who invented the QWERTY keyboard design?
What is one of the main reasons why QWERTY became the standard keyboard layout?

options.label: A
options.text: It was designed to keep typewriter keys from jamming.

options.label: B
options.text: It was the result of a cartel agreements among typewriter manufacturers.

options.label: C
options.text: It was the most efficient layout for typing.

options.label: D
options.text: It was the first keyboard layout to be patented.

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the keyboard layout that Christopher Latham Sholes developed in 1873?
What is the name of the company that Remington merged with to form a trust in the 1890s?
What is the name of the keyboard layout that Christopher Latham Sholes developed in 1889, just before his death?

title: Can you solve the killer robo-ants riddle? - Dan Finkel

multiple-choice.question: What is the speed at which the robo-ants will walk inside their habitat?
What will happen to the robo-ants if they bump into each other or hit a dead end?

options.label: A
options.text: They will turn on their lasers and break free

options.label: B
options.text: They will instantly turn around and walk back the way they came

multiple-choice.question: What is the key to stopping the robo-ants before they break free?

options.label: A
options.text: Placing the vacuum nozzles at random locations in the habitat

options.label: B
options.text: Placing the vacuum nozzles at intersections where three or four tubes meet

options.label: C
options.text: Placing the vacuum nozzles at the dead ends of the habitat

options.label: D
options.text: Placing the vacuum nozzles at the starting point of the habitat

multiple-choice.question: Why is it sufficient to find a solution for a single ant walking without interruption for less than 5 minutes?

options.label: A
options.text: Because the robo-ants are identical and can be treated as a single entity

options.label: B
options.text: Because the robo-ants are programmed to follow the same path

options.label: C
options.text: Because the identities of individual ants don’t matter

options.label: D
options.text: Because the habitat is a closed system

multiple-choice.question: Which two intersections should you pick to place the vacuum nozzles?

title: Four billion years of evolution in six minutes - Prosanta Chakrabarty

multiple-choice.question: According to the biologist, why do we need to understand evolution the right way?

options.label: A
options.text: To understand how to treat other life on earth and each other in terms of race and gender.

options.label: B
options.text: To know where we came from and to understand our place in the world.

options.label: C
options.text: To learn how to walk and talk.

options.label: D
options.text: To understand how to treat plants and bacteria.

multiple-choice.question: What is the single-celled organism that all life on earth came from?
What is the process by which organisms that best fit an environment survive and get to reproduce, while those that are less fit slowly die off?
According to the biologist, why do we think we're special?

options.label: A
options.text: Because we're the only species on earth.

options.label: B
options.text: Because we're the only species that can walk and talk.

options.label: C
options.text: Because we think plants and bacteria are primitive.

options.label: D
options.text: Because we're the only species that can learn.

multiple-choice.question: What is the biologist's analogy for understanding our place in the world?
